This is our full kit to convert the Solidoodle 2 (might be other solidoodles that this works on) with an E3D version 6 hot end to a bowden feed design.  If your extruder motor jigsaw puzzle (the clear plasitc thing on your extruder is still functional you do NOT need to print the extruder_motor_jigsaw)  The funnel should connect right in.  This replaces part of the x-axis carriage and feed system.  You will also need 4mm OD 2mm ID teflon tubing and Push in to Connect Pneumatic Straight Fitting 1/8" PT x 5/32" both can be found on Amazon.   
Updated.. Replaced motor mount with one that actually works. - I was able to print it as is with no support.  PLA filament.

If your jigsaw extruder pieces are still in tact you do not need to print the extruder motor jigsaw.  Screw a push to fit 5/32 fitting into the end of the funnel.  Connect tubing to the push to fit.  mount motor into the motor mount and bolt onto the filament mount holes on the back with the end of the motor facing out to the side.  remove x axis assembly and replace with the bar mount and x-axis back mount and lock the e3d into place with the bar end. With this setup our printer prints  abs, pla, t-glase, nylon and ninja flex (ninja flex needed a little help due to popping out of the extruder motor gears.

Warmers can easily be put in pockets, gloves, and boots, but how do we keep our core nice and toasty?  
SNOW HEAT!  
Just place a small to large sized Hot Hands warmer in the basket, attach a lanyard, and hang it around your neck. Then, adjust the lanyard so the warmer sits inside your coat at just the right spot to keep you warm.   
BONUS! Slick graphics on the front make SNOW HEAT a great holiday gift. Give an original - give SNOW HEAT!

The SNOW HEAT sample shown was printed in ABS, but PLA should work fine too. The two files print in about 3 hours total time. Below are the settings I used to get the above print: .2 Layer height
.35 First layer
30% infill
Lighter settings might work also.
3mm brim is needed to keep corners from shrinking. Add quarters or washers on top of brim and inside the basket once the base grid is done printing. Finishing
The front clips may need to be filed slightly if too tight.

title: Remote fan mount for E3D Hotend

description.text:
These parts allow you to use a 19mm ID hose (like from a CPAP) to route air to a E3D v5 or v6 hotend from a remote 40mm fan.
Designed for use in an enclosed printer. Update. After putting the first version together and testing it, I made several changes to improve the airflow. Finally, I decided to see if I could turn the axial 40mm fan into a centrifugal fan. I cut the fan out of the housing and installed it in the new fan base I designed. The
second version flows significantly more air. Update. After extensive testing, I'm happy to report that the
centrifugal modification works. It still has less airflow than the stock
fan. I was able to make prints of over 7 hours long with ABS with no
problems. The bottom two fins of the heat sink do get pretty hot, so chances are that there would be problems using it to print PLA.
The walls of the remote fan mount are 1.5mm, so I used 2 perimeters with a width of 0.35mm.   Support is needed for the centrifugal conversion fan base. Printed in ABS.

comments.text: The CPAP hose is flexible, you can bend it in about a 5" circle.  It is harder to compress, much like a Bowden tube.  So your best bet is to run an arch in it like the Bowden setup.
comments.author: RCENGR

comments.text: I tried something like this on the Rostock Max with an 80mm x 20mm fan and a used hose from a bissell SpotBot.  It worked beautifully... until I had to construct an enclosure for the build chamber, at which point, the hose would crash into the enclosure.
comments.author: soychicka

comments.text: There is air flowing out, but it's pretty light.  Once I test it with the hot end I'll know if it is enough or if more changes are needed.
comments.author: RCENGR

Nice idea, but i guess theres no air coming out at the end.
Unfortunately, these axial fans do not create enough air pressure for such applications.

Simple, retro, and classy, this "Now Playing" album holder is just what every audio aficionado needs.

title: Carrier for Sparkfun RS232 level shifter

description.text:
I have an LCD that requires level shifting before I can connect it to my PC.  I purchased a Sparkfun PRT-00133 RS232 level shifter for this very reason, but it doesn't have any mounting holes (and the LCD doesn't anyway).
The solution I came up with was to print a carrier, and then I could attach the PCB to it, and then double stick tape everything to my LCD.  The PCB attaches to the carrier via the included jackscrews.

Print this part with the DB9 end facing down, so that you can take advantage of the draft I added that precludes the need for support material (i.e. you can print this on a MakerBot).  It's also better to not waste ABS anyway, right?

comments.text: I rescaled this designed to fit a different RS232 to TTL converter. I plan on adding pictures in the "I Made One" option of both the original one I printed, and the one that fits my adapter. I used yours, my board, and a caliper to get the scaling correct. Should my version be posted as a remix of your design? It isn't an exact fit, as I had to drill out the screw holes in the finished print.
comments.author: Mikkel1955

author: dmatsumoto

description.text:
Customizable cylindrical containers with lids that twist on.  Use the customizer to generate base, lid, and optional separator parts for multi-chamber containers.  Multiple styles are available.  
Several example stl files are included.

To make a container, you'll want to make a base and lid part, and maybe some separators for multi-chamber containers.  Most of the parameters should be fairly straightforward and are described below.  Sizes are specified for the interior of the container, to make it easier to design the container to fit specific objects.  The "part gap" may take some testing to get right for your printer, it adjusts how tightly the lid and base fit.  With my printer, printing the parts one at a time gives more consistent results when trying to fine-tune the part gap parameter.  
Configurable Parameters:  
part - Type of part to make, base, separator, or lid.  The separator is for multiple-chamber containers (you may want to build the container upside down, with the lid on bottom when using separators).  
inside diameter - Minimum diameter of the inside of the container in mm (container will be larger)  
interior height - Amount of height this part adds to the overall interior space of the container in mm (exterior dimensions will be larger).  
style - Style of the container: round (straight cylindrical sides), round thin (same as round, but with interior cutouts to make the walls thinner), tapered (thinner at top or bottom), polygon (flat sides, helps with grip), crown (blended between round and polygon), and flipped crown (same as crown, but upside down)  
number of sides - Number of sides for the polygon and crown styles.  
minimum wall thickness - Thickness to use for the thinnest vertical wall sections.  
top bottom thickness - Thickness used for the bottom of the base and the top of the lid.  
lip height - Height of the container lip with the bayonet threads.  Values of around 2-3mm seem to work well.  
bayonet depth - depth of the bayonet thread used to hold the parts together.  Larger containers may need larger values, but values around 0.5mm seem to work well for small to medium containers.  
part gap - This is the amount of space between the bayonet threads.  Use this to adjust how tightly the parts fit (smaller value results in a tighter fit).  It may take some trial and error to fine tune this parameter for your printer.  
support material should only be needed on the optional separator pieces.

description.text:
is in the Black Hills of South Dakota, very near to Mt. Rushmore. It commemorates the Lakota leader, Crazy Horse, he is depicted riding a horse, and pointing to the horizon.. It's construction started in 1948 by Korczak Ziolkowski, and when it is finished, it may be the biggest sculpture in the world! For comparison, the heads of the presidents in Mt. Rushmore are only about half of Crazy Horse's. (Wikipedia)  
At MiniWorld, we want to celebrate Thanksgiving Day with this free model, show us pictures if you print it or buy it! Don't forget to check out our other models!

I modeled in parametric, it was a real challenge to model the face, and I came up with an easy way to "sculpt" the mountain - it's fun to push software in a direction that is not necessarily the one it was made for!

During a trip to South Dakota, I visited both Mt. Rushmore and Crazy Horse memorial, I can't believe nobody knows about the second! That's why I decided to model this for the world to see. I learned a lot about Native American culture by visiting the nearby museum too. The idea of MiniWorld originated from a visually-impaired friend who asked me if I could use 3D printing to help her and others "see" the world - with miniature models, they can understand shapes and sizes of the most famous landmarks and travel with their hands.
MiniWorld is the collection of 3D printed landmarks from around the world! All my things I model myself by hand and brain, please give credit. It's all about spreading culture!

• No support needed
• ABS, 230 Celsius
• Infill 15% Very easy print, the arch doesn't need support.

comments.text: So how did you model the face using a parametric program?
comments.author: Xavi009

comments.text:
It was very hard, it is using revolutions, drafted cuts and extrusions, angled planes, etc.
Definitely the hardest to do is human faces and bodies. The Christ the Redeemer, Statue of Liberty, and Reclining Buddha were big challenges too. I know my human figures end up looking robot-like and not very "natural", but I like to make them myself from scratch and also that they have a certain style.

comments.text: Couple things, first of all the X axis usually isn't the one that suffers backlash. Second, putting that up there may stabilize the platform's play but you should have weights on the axis support from factory to stop that, and even without them, it doesn't make much difference unless you use Z hop. It also makes your entire tray susceptible to sway if that bar ever gets bent, which is common. It will act as a brace and now that theres 2 points of contact, it will impart more than double the torque on the guide bars. The newer makerbot style repraps (like your ultimaker) have one bearing there for a reason. The one upgrade that I notice helps, is the upper stabilizer that mounts to the roof of the machine, over the z axis. Im not sure whats going on with yours, but I suspect either you have a problem and went about fixing the wrong thing, or you have an extremely fast Z movement without acceleration. Ive never heard of people getting Z backlash, only X and Y. If yours has a problem, perhaps check the upper Z bearing? On the Makerbot, Mbot, and a bunch of others, left that upper hole blank for a reason; not just to save money. They're blank to help stop any torque sway (which happens to almost every machine that wasn't shipped with an upper brace. Z axis warrenty replacements have plagued them, and as a result, you will see the upper stabalizers on most newer machines. If you have layer artifacts, chances are, the bearings and rods are where you need to look. Your bearing may also need to be lubed if you havnt done so. That silicon lube will last about 3-6 months before it gets too dirty, depending on the cleanliness at the machine's location. You gotta keep everything slick man, if you don't, it will have HEAVY impact on the print. Especially if you don't use a belt tensioner, which they recommend for the ultimaker. If you haven't lubbed it, I would just throw it out and get a new one, theyre cheap and make a big difference. You might also try Z hop on your current hardware to see if that helps fix the problem. It will hop every time it retracts and if you have It set properly, it will "re-set" the platform as it comes back up. But again, its usually not a Z lash problem. The ultimakes is known for it's speed, so I highly advise looking at those bearings, a few belt tensioners (printable - but don't use PLA! Anything else is ok. Once it gets warm, it slowly looses its ability to hold tension and will just fall off after a long print. ColorFab's XT will work, however.) And look for braces for various components.

comments.text: what I did to fix this issue was corrected the firmware on the default axis steps for Z. it comes stock at 2268 when it should be 2267.72 the round up on the default axis steps per unit is a whole layer height. Also I started printing to the correct layer height, see if you set your slicing software to slice at .3 layer height because of the 5/16-18 z axis screw the stepper motor would need to be able to step 42.523033309709426 but if you set your .2963 the stepper motor will step 42 steps exactly. now lets say you choose not to set a custom layer height well the stepper motor will still take 42 steps but the coordination with your extruder motor and the actual layer height will be out of sync causing a backlash layered effect.

description.text: The Uzebox is a retro-minimalist 8-bit open source game console based on an AVR 8-bit general purpose microcontroller. It is available commercially at Adafruit.com and boasts over 80 games, tools and demos all made by an ever growing and enthusiastic community. Up to now, the Uzebox was so minimalist it didn't even have an enclosure. Well...no more! Uzebox home: http://uzebox.org Uzebox forums thread about discussing the enclosure progress: http://uzebox.org/forums/viewtopic.php?f=4&t=2070 Uzebox kits can be bought at https://www.adafruit.com/product/1291

-Printed on Ultimaker 2  
-Faberdashery PLA used: Arctic white, Classic Black, Robot Silver, Mercury Red.  
-Print spec: 225 deg hot end, 70 heated bed, 30mm/s. Used support structure for top shell.  
-6 x 3mmx12mm self taping screws  
-For the buttons, it's easier to print the Button-power-cap.STL, Button-power-shaft.STL, button-reset-cap.STL, Button-reset-shaft.STL flat face down and glue them using strong glue (i.e CrazyGlue).

title: Training Grips for Medela Baby Bottles

description.text: These two little grip rings go on a 5oz Medela baby bottle, to help tiny hands learn to grasp and manipulate. One just wedges onto the bottle, the other gets locked on under the lid. The one that goes under the lid has little crush tabs on top to ensure a good fit regardless of printer calibration, and built in supports for expediency.

I recommend printing in a food-safe filament because it will end up in your baby's mouth, although it's not intended for a chew toy. If you use a heat-resistant material such as "t-glase" (which is PETT) then it can be slobbered and sterilized. Monitor your baby while she's using it, in case your printing skills don't hold up to her breaking skills.

author: carver

title: Small parts bins for Harbor Freight parts storage case (#93928)

description.text:
7 different versions of small parts bins for the famed Harbor Freight portable parts storage cases (#93928). These portable cases are the best you can buy for the money right now compared to the much more expensive Sortimo cases and generally hold up well. I posted similar bins for the Stanley 014725 cases which have a slightly different height: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:579033 Harbor Freight does not sell extra bins which usually means you run out of the smaller ones quickly when storing electronic parts for instance. I also wanted bins with smaller compartments to store resistors/capacitors/etc. And of course you can print in different colors instead of being stuck with yellow. length (without lip): 53 mm
width (without lip): 38 mm
height (without feet): 47 mm

PLA, .2mm layer, 10% infill (does not matter as the walls are thin).  
I recommend to print these upside down (except the ones with no compartments), i.e. with the opening on the bottom. The bottom of the bin needs some cleanup afterwards as it will print partially in the air.  
You can print them right upside up, but you will need supports due to the feet. The cleanup of the supports is somewhat difficult but possible with a sharp utility knife (put on some gloves or you'll cut yourself).  
I did experiment with detached feet (to be glued on afterwards), the results were not satisfactory so far. The feet never locate properly and/or the surfaces are not level enough to glue properly.

author: Adaminspaceship

title: Boo's Adjustable Mini Kossel Hotbed and Glass Bed Clamp V2

description.text:
26/12/2014: Modified height a little, and increased the tolerance so that it's not so tight.   
Here's a two-part clamp for adding a hot-bed and glass bed set to a Mini Kossel. The bottom part lifts the hotbed above the aluminium frame so that the two thermistor terminals don't short out. That part has a little embedded trench to allow for a couple wires and solder to be added to connect the thermistor without problems. The top part is the sliding clamp which is used to firmly press against the 170 mm glass bed and hold it in place. The design is such that the full surface of the glass plate is available for printing; the glass is held by firm sidewards pressure and downward pressure from the top clamp being pushed down by the screws. It's quite a tight fit, so if people are having problems I will adjust the tolerances a bit. I purchased the hotbed from AliExpress for about $20.

You will need two M3x10 screws for each clamp. I used M3x12 and snipped off a couple mm off the end, worked just fine. Put the screws through both parts first, then screw onto the screws in the 1515 tube but don't tighten. Slide the part over the hotbed edges, with the hotbed going between the two parts. Now start to tighten clamps a bit each, making sure the glass is centered and pushed down, by pushing the sliding part against the edge of the glass and holding firmly while you tighten. When it's all finished, the glass should be held firmly in place against the hotbed.

comments.text: Thank you for this great design! Now I can finally use the full print bed.

title: Higher motor end for Rostock Mini Pro

description.text:
The stock motor ends for the Rostock Mini Pro lack a few millimetres if you decide to add a display adapter to the RAMPS print and want to keep it tucked away below the printer.  
These motor ends are 8mm higher than the originals.

The motor sits roughly in the middle, so it is being moved up by 4mm, whereas you get 8mm less total height and 8mm shorter belt length if you keep the rod ends flush with the printed parts (assuming they were before). You can adjust by either  
1) cutting the belts to the new length (they should be around 8mm shorter than before, but check each belt individually before cutting), and adjust the print height by 8mm, or  
2) Lifting the rods 4mm up in the new bottom part, or lift the top ends 4mm higher up, keeping the belt length and losing 4mm total print height, or  
3) replacing belt and rods with new ones that are 8mm longer, keeping total print height and leaving you with enough parts to consider starting to build another printer. :-)  
Adjust the height in firmware or EEPROM if it has changed, and perform a calibration in any case, simply because you never know if a fraction of a millimetre difference in one of the towers will cause a large change in nozzle height.

description.text: Very simple spool for filament.  Three printed parts, 1 bearing, 2 feet of 5/16 threaded rod, 2 large washers, 8 nuts.  Very smooth performance.  Picked up bearing at Sears.  20 mm x 8 MM with ID .375 in.

Print out 2 cones and base., carefully smooth bearing hole with light sandpaper. Press bearing into hole with vice. Cut threaded rods.
Install vertical threaded rod into bearing, put a nut on both sides.
Screw threaded rod into base. Put 2 nuts on each rod for 'feet'.
Mount spool- big washer, cone pointed up, spool, cone pointed down, big washer, wing nut. All Set. I added an optional 'break' to put some friction on the spool in case it spins too fast. just place it between 2 nuts. Use 4 6" sections of threaded rod for one unit(2 feet)

title: Zero Point Energy Field Manipulator (Gravity Gun) 1:1 Scale

description.text: This gravity gun (from half life)is accurate (as much as I could make it) and just all around awesome looking. It is sliced into multiple pieces, to make printing easier, and so that it can be as close to 1:1 scale it can be, and I am now proud to say that it is, in fact, 1:1 scale. SImilar to pleppik's portal gun, this is a gargantuan project, and will take a while, if you are brave enough to try. Enjoy.

Scale every piece except the front body pieces to 800%. Scale the front body pieces to 780% and any pins or claws directly attached to it to 790%. Requires no support. Warning: Some of these pieces will take up your entire platform if you are using a Replicator 1, but they do not go any farther than that. Assembly requires glue for all pins except those on the claws. For assembly instructions, look at the file labeled "Assembly_instructions".

title: Linux Doorbell WiFi enabled (Raspberry Pi A+)

description.text:
I got annoyed by our doorbell (very loud and heartstopping schrill sound) and I startet building one using a arduino controller but then I realised that it would be much more fun to be able to change/ install doorbell sounds via network on the doorbell, no SD card removing and plugging into the cardreader and plugging back in, just ssh or ftp into your doorbell and upload a new soundfile!  
When the new Raspberry Pi model A+ came out it was setteled and I needed a nice enclosure for the electronics and the two loudspeakers.  
You even can play internet radio, or make announcements with it.  
Updated the python script, added a sql-lite db for logging rings added a command to pause my mpd music player via network in case somebody rings and I hear music and overhear the "bell".

Printing the case isn't easy but its doable, I included my gcode file created with Simplify3D for my Makergear M2 printer. I printed this with PLA and used a raft. The Raspberry Pi Model A+ is mounted on two slides (see included file) which fit into the enclosure. The doorbell button is connected to GPIO7 and is beeing read via event_detect (interrupt) in python (see small included script). I soldered a 20nF ceramic cap between GPIO7 and GND to block interferences coming in over the cabel and also a 4.7k pullup resistor to 3.3V. The loudspeakers are driven by a Stereo 3.7W Class D Audio Amplifier - MAX98306 which I bought here: http://www.exp-tech.de/Shields/Audio/Stereo-3-7W-Class-D-Audio-Amplifier-MAX98306.html The loudspeakers are 3" 4 Ohms 3Watt and have to be glued into the case: http://www.exp-tech.de/lautsprecher-3-durchmesser-4-ohm-3-watt?___SID=U Usually in Germany there is a little 8V/1A AC transformer in the electrical cabinet for the standard doorbell. I replaced it with a 5V/ 2.4A DC switching supply for DIN-Rail from Reichelt electronics: https://secure.reichelt.de/Schaltnetzteile-fuer-Hut-Schiene/MW-DR-15-5/3//index.html?ACTION=3&GROUPID=6539&ARTICLE=148095&SEARCH=MW%20DR-15-5&OFFSET=500&WKID=0& The python script uses sox (play) to play the sound files, so you have to install a few things first: sudo apt-get install sox lame libsox-fmt-mp3 after that you should be able to play sounds: play some-soundfile.mp3 use alsamixer to change the volume. The script expects the soundfiles in the folder "/home/pi/door-bell/sounds" and plays them randomly.

Can you suggest a comparable speaker from Amazon?  This is my first Raspberry Pi project and I'm really intrigued because I don't have a doorbell in the house right now.

" This is my first Raspberry Pi project and I have very little electronic experience so is there any way you can post a picture of the how the wires / resistor / and ceramic cap connect the doorbell to the Raspberry Pi? That would be great. If not . . . perhaps a diagram?

comments.text: Good to hear that you like it! I've added a little circuit diagram to the images section (you have to click on  the 'toggle largeview' button to see the whole circuit diagram). I hope this will make it clear what I meant, I used a sourface mount capacitor but any ceramic capacitor will do...

comments.text: Ok, it looks like I am making some progress. I have been working on the Python backend mostly to get email and a photo when the button is pressed. As for hardware, I've got the capacitor and it seems like I might still be getting some "ghost" pushes. I have an LED in the circuit though so I'll take that out so that it is exactly like your setup.

comments.text: No I don't have double doorbell rings, except if people push the doorbell button serveral times, which in the beginning lead me to thinking I had ghost pushes but they wheren't. The pi-bell was just playing one song for each push on the button.

comments.text: I noticed yesterday that my ghost presses are when light switches or the air conditioner are flipped on in my house. If I go into the bathroom and flip the light switch on, the doorbell rings. So it is definitely interference causing issues. I will try different capacitors and see if that makes a difference.
comments.author: uli

comments.text: Yep that could definetly do it, the doorbell cable is most likely not shielded so you get a lot of spikes and noise.
comments.author: erocm123

comments.text: Thanks for the article. A little over my head at this time, but I'll re-read it a couple times and do some research and hopefully I can figure it out. Man, I thought the hardware part of this project was going to be super simple. Guess I was wrong. :)

comments.text: Welcome to the real world of electronics =:) but hey what would be the fun of it if everything would just work. In my experience I learned the most when something didn't go as expected.

comments.text: So I have added another 1K resistor into the io-line as suggested. When I flick the lights on in the bathroom I no longer get a false positive door ring. This may have solved my problem, but I did get one "ghost ring" this morning at 6:35 am which I'm not sure about. Maybe it was a fluke. I'll have to wait and see, but hopefully I've got things figured out!

based on drawings for a working demonstration of a Root's steam engine. I'm not sure exactly how the crank will turn out, but different production methods should be able to be used to reproduce this model once completed.
the models are "drilled" but not tapped. The OpenSCAD source is included. sizes from the drawings are:
Cover to Valve cover setscrews, tap #4-40x 0.19" deep TYP x 8
Exhaust ports, tap .25-28 NF x 0.25" deep TYP x 2
Pressure port, tap .25-28 NF x 0.25" deep TYP x 1
Valve Cover to Body set bolts, tap #6-32 x 0.31" TYP x 12
Valve to Valve Shaft grub screw, #4-40 TYP x1 The only component not shown in these STL files is the SPACER.
OD 0.5" x ID 0.32" thickness to suit.
Not yet assembled to verify what size or thickness this should be to complete the model. Added 20141207
spacer, which is a piece that sits between the valve cover and the valve to provide thrust support on the side of the valve. This will need a slight adjustment to tune to your model.
valve lockring, which is due to the set screw hole in the valve being impractical for securing the vale to the valve shaft.
The valve locking uses m3 nut traps and an m3 setscrew to lock the valve shaft to the valve at the appropriate angle to time the engine.
drawings taken from Steam & Stirling Engines You Can Build Book 2 - A compilation of engines from Live Steam between 1982 and 1993.

title: Director's Chair
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I built a model of a director's chair. I chose to build this because it was an interesting design and it would be a cool finished product. To create this finished model I first had to create a design on Inventor. My original design had to be revised several times because of the limited abilities of the Maker Bot. I had to make two solid legs rather than four individual legs and the back of the chair all had to be on the same layer. Although there were many changes, the finished product turned out fantastic!

Some things to remember when building this design is that the bottom layers will cool a lot faster than the top layers, causing the bottom to shrink and part of the product to be uneven. To create a smoother, cleaner finished product use a heated build platform so the entire design is cooling and shrinking together. Also, because it is a larger design make sure the platform is big enough to support the entire rack. If it is not large enough, the product will begin to build off the side of the platform and will not be a successful creation.

title: Holy Folding Bat Hanger
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Holy Super Folding Bat Hanger!!!! Can you just imagine how embarrassed Batman would be if every time he had respond to the bat signal, he had to stop and iron his cape? I can just hear Catwoman saying "Batman, you look purrrrrrrfectly divine". Even the most dastardly criminals would be envious.  
Perfect for travel, this hanger can be folded to take up less room in your luggage. Small enough to fit into a car glove box so when you need to hang something on that tiny little hook the car companies provide, this is ready to go to work.

You can print all pieces separately, or you can print using the setup build plate. It will fit on the Rep2. I recommend using at least 25% infill for strength.  You will find there is a built-in support on the hook that will need to be removed.  Some sanding may be required  depending on the print. I found I needed to sand down the pin a little near the bumps.  
After printing all pieces,  Align the wings, and slide the pin down from the top. The hook is setup as a twist lock. Hold the hook with the two down pieces so they are along side of the hinge bump. This will prevent the hanger from collapsing onto itself when in use. Turn the pin from the point end to lock it into the hook. Once everything is in place, glue the point to the hinge pin. If everything is aligned correctly, each time you set it up, the pin will be straight on the bottom.To collapse, just twist the pin from the point end, remove the hook and fold the wings. The Hinge pin cannot be removed after full assembly.

This is an Advnet Calender used to count down the days until Christmas. It has a 24 day count-down so starting on December 1st you remove the highest number block (24) and flip it around to show green. Then each day do the same until you have 1 day left which is Christmas Eve.  
I created this in Tinkercad and Printed it in ABS on my Davinci 1.0 printer. The design took two runs. One for the tree and base and a second for the calendar blocks.  
I printed it at 0.4mm height and 20% fill.  
I used supports on the tree base.

description.text: 3D Scan from the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Egyptian Art Gallery #115. Details on the piece are here: Met Online I've included the original OBJ from 123D Catch and corresponding materials file (it imports into Blender perfectly). The top of the model is messed up, but the STL file has been sculpted to print normally.

Print the STL file. I ran this through Slic3r with 15% infill at .25mm layer height on my Prusa i3 and PLA filament. Should scale up alright.  
If you want to make higher-res versions, you can manipulate the OBJ file. Just be aware the top of the sculpture didn't capture in the scan, so you'll need to use Sculptris or Blender or the like to fix it for printing.

title: RepRapPro Mendel Lugless Dial Indicator Holder

description.text: Holder for lugless dial indicators that fits on to the RepRapPro Mendel Mono. Customizable for a range of dial sizes.

Can be fitted using the built in hot end height adjuster, but also has holes to mount with m3 screws. 
If you use the clamp version then supports will be necessary.  The upright orientation may be better depending on your support settings.  Turning the clamp off will set up holes for set screws, the holes likely will be tight enough to thread m3 screws through. 
There is a limited range of dial sizes that will produce a usable holder, but it should be obvious through simple visual inspection of the model.  
It came out quite usable when I printed with .4mm layer height, 30% rectangular grid fill, and supports.

description.text: Small funeel. It was inteded for kitchen use, but can be scaled to other uses (like mechanics). Enjoy!

It was made from a profile in Inkscape (draw a line, adjust curvature, covert to path, more teaking.). Then I converted to openscad via Inkscape Openscad converter (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24808) and some tweaks (translation, rotate_extrude instead of linear_extrude). Printed with makerbot 5th generation.

author: Mape

description.text:
This is the main logo you see in all of my designs that are tagged in
the Ghostly Vinyl Challenge. Feel free anyone to use this logo, and it
is fully customizable with the model which has no 3D Text. You can
also use this as a badge, bottle opener, or anything.
P.S It does open bottles :)
A fun coaster for kids (and adults) inspired in African elephants and African art

Are you lucky enough to be single and have a bathroom all to yourself? If you want to get your toothbrush out on your bathroom countertop with only a small amount of space while looking stylish at the same time, this toothbrush holder is for you. Geometric inspired design achieves function with pleasing aesthetics. Don't forget to upload your pictures. Enjoy!  
Note: Because I don't have access to fancy parametric 3D modelers, the .stl file might import into your slicer very tiny; I had to scale mine up about 500%. I'm working on fixing that for the future, so hold on to your seats! I apologize for the inconvenience.

comments.text: Scale should be 2.54.  Drawing was scaled for inches rather than mm, so scale by 254% to print correctly.

author: bmwjan

title: Ghostly Vinyl USB powered speaker kit

description.text: This little set up is something every music lover should have . Their very own 'Ghostly Vinyl' USB powered speakers! All you need is a cheap DIY speaker and amplifier kit and an old USB cable. Now your music is truly portable since they can be powered any USB port or USB backup powerpack!!

Simply print the parts, then with a few simple screws it all goes together. Oh and I chopped up and old USB cable to get the power instead of the cumbersome 'AA' batterypack...  
I printed the speaker lid with standard cura support settings (under the needle on the speaker lid, the arm was just bridged)  
I printed the speaker base with no supports.  
I printed the electrics ghost box with cura support settings set to 80degree overhang.  
Sorry about the overall finish on my pics, looks a bit 'liney', that's a mixture of bad filament and bad photography...  
Im sure if I had my very own 'MakerBot Replicator Mini Compact 3D Printer' and Makerbot filament, the results would be astonishing on future projects!!!
